statement:
Bruhat decomposition is the name for the fact that
$B\backslash G/B = W$, where $G$ is a reductive group, $B$ a Borel
subgroup, and $W$ the Weyl group. Less canonically, one can write
$G = BWB$.

In the case of the general linear group $G = GL_n$, $B$ is the group of
nonsingular upper triangular matrices, and $W$ is the collection of
permutation matrices (and is isomorphic to $S_n$). Any nonsingular
matrix can thus be written uniquely as a product of an upper triangular
matrix, a permutation matrix, and another upper triangular matrix.
